awd_titl_txt: EAGER: DECOMPOSING COVID-19 VIRUS USING THE DUAL ACTION OF MICROWAVES AND PLASMA
awd_abstract_narration:
The medical-supply shortage during the COVID-19 pandemic has created an unprecedented need for disinfecting medical personal protective equipment (PPE). Microwaves and plasma can effectively inactivate microbial pathogens and may be used for disinfecting contaminated medical equipment. This research project presents an exploratory approach to address some of the challenges created by the current pandemic. The researchers will investigate the effectiveness of the dual action of microwaves and plasma in disinfecting PPE contaminated with enveloped viruses, such as the COVID-19, at low temperatures. If successful, this process will have the ability to decontaminate heat-sensitive materials (e.g., masks, gloves, and gowns) by subjecting them to microwave-assisted low-temperature plasma with controlled intensity and density to avoid compromising their structural integrity. The proposed disinfection approach is potentially transformative and may also inspire fundamental changes in how communities use and recycle certain objects, as well as address challenges beyond the current COVID-19 pandemic. For instance, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that each year healthcare-associated infections kill more people worldwide than other incidents such as AIDS, breast cancer, or car accidents. The outcomes of the proposed research will significantly contribute to alleviating this problem by presenting effective techniques for disinfecting medical equipment. Thus, it will have tremendous environmental and economic impacts to geographical locations with limited consistent access to fresh medical supplies, e.g., rural communities in the U.S. and other developing countries.

This multidisciplinary research will analyze key parameters affecting microwave and plasma disinfection mechanisms of contaminated PPE at low and nondestructive temperatures. Numerical solutions for equations describing electromagnetic-wave and plasma interactions in an overmoded microwave cavity will be developed. These solutions will be used to design an experimental system to apply variable intensities of microwaves and low-temperature plasma to contaminated specimens. An optimized system will be built with high precision to analyze the parameters affecting the decontamination process. The effectiveness of the developed system in inactivating enveloped viruses, such as COVID-19, will be tested using influenza A viruses. The effective destruction of influenza A virus would guarantee the system's capability to destroy COVID-19. The microwave and plasma intensities and exposure time will be varied while the specimen's temperature, humidity in the device chamber, and the viability of the virus are being monitored. The aim is to determine the effective combination of microwave and plasma doses, exposure time, humidity, and temperature that can destroy the virus. The proposed approach has several advantages over conventional disinfection approaches using chemicals, including speed, convenience for repeated use, continuous availability, environmental friendliness, and safety. The research can potentially be extended to explore disinfecting objects contaminated with other pathogens such as fungal cells and bacteria, in addition to enveloped and non-enveloped viruses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the critical need for effective disinfection methods, especially for medical personal protective equipment (PPE). This project aimed to develop a novel disinfection device that uses both microwaves and plasma to inactivate microbial pathogens, particularly on heat-sensitive materials.

The primary goal of this project was to design, develop, and optimize a disinfection device utilizing microwaves and plasma as core disinfecting agents. The innovative approach combined the dual-action of microwaves and low-temperature atmospheric-pressure plasma to achieve rapid and effective decontamination of PPE and other medical instruments without damaging heat-sensitive materials such as masks, gloves, and gowns.

The project explored the fundamental interactions between electromagnetic waves and plasma in a controlled environment, leading to the development of a unique microwave-plasma system capable of disinfecting contaminated PPE. A significant achievement was the successful deactivation of enveloped viruses (such as those similar to COVID-19) and bacteria without reaching temperatures that could compromise the integrity of the materials. This was accomplished by carefully adjusting the power and exposure times of both microwave and plasma sources to optimize disinfection while preserving the container's structural integrity.

Further intellectual contributions include the development of a novel antenna design that improved energy distribution within the disinfection chamber, enhancing the uniformity of treatment. The use of machine learning algorithms to optimize antenna performance demonstrates a cross-disciplinary approach that combines electrical engineering with artificial intelligence.

The broader impacts of this project are multifaceted, encompassing environmental, economic, and public health benefits. The disinfection device developed under this project offers a chemical-free, cost-effective alternative to traditional disinfection methods that often rely on harmful chemicals. This reduces the potential health risks to operators and patients and minimizes environmental pollution associated with chemical waste.

Economically, the device's portability and rapid disinfection capabilities can significantly reduce costs for healthcare facilities, especially in rural and resource-limited settings where access to fresh medical supplies is inconsistent. By enabling on-site disinfection, the device eliminates the need to transport contaminated equipment to off-site facilities, saving time and reducing logistical challenges.

The potential applications of this technology are broad and extend beyond the specific virus that motivated its development. The system ability to disinfect various pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi, makes it a versatile tool for addressing healthcare-associated infections, which are a significant concern worldwide.

Moreover, this project has fostered educational and professional development opportunities, providing comprehensive training for graduate students. The research has been disseminated through high-impact conferences and journal publications, contributing to the broader scientific community's understanding of microwave and plasma disinfection technologies.

This NSF-funded project has successfully developed a novel microwave-plasma disinfection device with significant intellectual merit and broader impacts. The project's findings have demonstrated the potential for this technology to transform disinfection practices in healthcare settings, reduce environmental and health risks, and offer a cost-effective solution for resource-limited environments. The broader adoption of this technology could improve patient outcomes and lead to more sustainable and efficient healthcare practices worldwide.
